newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: South Korea strengthens police use of firearms.
newsitem.headline: South Korea strengthens police use of firearms.

text.p: The South Korean government plans to ease regulations on police use of firearms as part of a crackdown on growing violent crimes, the domestic Yonhap news agency said on Sunday.
The revision to the law governing police operations would also allow riot police to strengthen crackdowns on violent student demonstrations, Yonhap said.
"Existing equipment such as plastic shields are almost useless in battling attacks with steel pipes and molotov cocktails," Yonhap quoted a senior party official as saying.
Traditionally, police have been restricted from using fire arms because civilian arms ownership has been totally banned in South Korea with the exception of hunting guns.
"We consider introducing multi-purpose equipment, for example, specially-designed armoured vehicles, and replacing plastic shields with transparent ones."
The move follows a wave of violent anti-government demonstrations in which both civilians and police have been injured.
Last month, a riot policeman died from head injuries when police stormed a Seoul university campus to end an occupation by students demanding reunification with communist North Korea.
Hundreds of police officers and students were also injured in the seven-day showdown on the Yonsei University campus in western Seoul.
Shocked by the worst campus violence since he took office in 1993, President Kim Young-sam has accused radical students of waging urban guerrilla warfare and vowed to punish violent activists.
On Sunday, state KBS television said prosecutors would seek homicide charges against about 10 students arrested in the Yonsei demonstration in relation to the policeman's death.
Prosecution officials could not be immediately reached for comment.
